Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Self-Assembly of Multicomponent Nanostructures
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many of the remarkable features seen in nature, ranging from the strength of spider silk to the light-harvesting ability of plant leaves, arises from sophisticated, multicomponent architectures. These biological nanostructures are comprised of multiple, discrete components that are assembled with nanoscale (one billionth of a meter scale) precision into a highly integrated functional system. Self-assembly offers a convenient, albeit often trial and error-based strategy, to make single-component, synthetic materials in the nanoscale regime. However, these systems rarely exhibit the high level of performance seen in natural systems due to the difficulties in reliably designing self-assembling systems composed of multiple, precisely positioned components. To address this challenge and progress toward higher levels of functional performance, Professors Parquette of The Ohio State University and Modarelli of The University of Akron, are developing strategies to self-assemble multiple, discrete building blocks into multicomponent architectures to serve as optoelectronic materials for solar energy conversion. Creating reliable strategies to create non-covalent architectures that rival the sophisticated systems in biology may enable new technologies capable of addressing societal problems in areas such as renewable energy, greenhouse gas conversion, and medicine. Additionally, this project is used as a platform to enhance public awareness of the potential role that science plays in addressing these issues. The research team continues to present science exhibitions at the Columbus Center of Science and Industry (COSI) to allow younger students to experience the hands-on excitement of scientific discovery. Also, the investigators use Ohio State's REEL program to offer opportunities for large numbers of undergraduate students to perform nanotechnology research in a teaching laboratory environment in addition to providing opportunities for undergraduates in the research laboratory. Professors Parquette and Modarelli provide research experiences to minority students in the area of nanotechnology through the NSF HBCU-RISE program and through the SROP (Summer Research Opportunities Program) at OSU.

The Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division supports the work of Professors Parquette and Modarelli, which aims to develop a versatile strategy to assemble multiple optoelectronic components into self-sorted domains that are integrated within a single nanostructure. This approach creates composite nanostructures using a sequential layer-by-layer strategy to organize pre-assembled systems into one architecture. The morphology, dimensions, and positional arrangement of the components are correlated with the corresponding photophysical properties, measured using ultrafast spectroscopic techniques. The research activities include: (1) the co-assembly of nanotube-polymer composites displaying a coaxial, bicontinuous array of conjugated polymers that establish a redox cascade; (2) the co-assembly of discrete, monomeric building blocks into composite structures comprised of separate, self-assembled nanostructures; (3) measurement of the photophysical properties of the assemblies via ensemble and single-molecule femtosecond spectroscopy; and (4) to measure photo-electrochemical coupling of aligned nanotube co-assemblies via surface-tracked scanning electrochemical microscopy (ST-SECM).This project integrates fundamental research with outreach and communication efforts to engage a diverse group of students in interdisciplinary science, and the community at large, to show how nanotechnology impacts their lives.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Biological cells exhibit a diverse range of highly functional capabilities that are unmatched in synthetic systems. These capabilities emerge from complex, hierarchal structures with an optimal arrangement of functional segments to perform a biological task. Thus, the challenge in supramolecular materials is to create multicomponent systems by the co-assembly of discrete, spatially sorted domains of components, and to control their higher level interactions. Although self-assembly has been a topic of study for at least two decades, the heuristic nature of the design process severely hampers application to many problems. This research offered a solution to create functional, multicomponent nanostructures via the predictable/designable assembly of small molecules and led to applications in optoelectronics, drug delivery and catalysis, which have been the subject of several patent applications. A pragmatic approach to assemble composite nanostructures composed of a self-assembled nanotube wrapped by a coaxial arrangement of multiple optoelectronic polymers using a sequential layer-by-layer strategy to organize the components into a single, architecture. Recently we developed a strategy to coat carbon nanotubes with another self-assembled nanotube by sliding self-assembled rings over the carbon nanotube, then fusing them into a distinct outer shell. This NSF-supported basic research has set the stage for potential strategies to address problems in greenhouse gas conversion, catalysis, anticancer drug delivery, optoelectronics and, more recently, diabetes treatment.

            The specific objectives of this research project were focused on the modular design and construction of self-assembled, nanostructures containing bicontinuous donor/acceptor heterojunctions with a long-term goal of introducing multichromophore gradients in the electron transport channel. A general strategy to assemble specific components, such as optoelectronic chromophores, catalytic moieties, enzymes, and anticancer drugs, into functional nanostructures has emerged from this work. In collaboration with Prof. David Modarelli, these nanomaterials were also studied using femtosecond spectroscopic techniques to correlate their structural features with the corresponding electronic properties. Over the last 3 years of this project, several assembled multicomponent systems composed of self-sorted, optoelectronic components were constructed. A strategy was developed whereby each component was introduced to the growing architecture using a sequential, “layer-by-layer” deposition process. This approach avoided intermolecular interactions among the building blocks from diverting the assembly path toward disparate, unpredictable endpoints.

            This work has also introduced a diverse group of undergraduate students to interdisciplinary science at the interface of chemistry and nanotechnology. In addition to working with students on research, the PI as been involved in actively mentoring students and student groups. An undergraduate club was created in the Center for Student Leadership and Service, called “Health Points: Pre-Health Connections & Volunteering” in 2016 with a student, Michael Chung, and and the PI serves as the club’s faculty advisor. This student club, which rose in membership to ~180 students, assists science students in their preparation for careers in the health sciences and connects students to science faculty, health practitioners and provides weekly opportunities for community service. The PI has also mentored the research of ~75 OSU undergraduate students over the last ~10 years, leading to several theses, Goldwater fellowships and the decision of many students to pursue Ph.D. degrees in chemistry. The PI leads a multi-investigator scientific team for the Center of Applied Plant Science (CAPS), which is comprised of faculty from CBC, Microbiology, and Engineering. This team focused on developing new strategies to sequester greenhouse gases from the atmosphere and convert them to value-added materials. Through his association with CAPS as the team leader, he has contributed to outreach videos discussing nanotechnology approaches toward greenhouse gas conversion to general audiences, via COSI’s “Portal to the Public” initiative.
